docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Terror of Childbirth,'' by Nicholas D. Kristof (Op-Ed, March 20): Approximately 20 other countries do a better job at keeping their childbearing women alive. Why suggest that the United States take up the challenge of exporting its birth practices to Africa? What is needed here and there to improve birthing conditions are increased quality of life, reduction in poverty and a functional health care system including an emphasis on midwifery care.
docs.abstract: Elizabeth Volkmann letter on Nicholas D Kristof's March 20 column calls for improving birthing conditions in United States as well as in poor African nations

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have worked in international health and development for nearly 30 years, and I want to congratulate Nicholas D. Kristof on his series of columns that illustrate all too clearly the challenges faced by women living in poor countries today (most recently ''Terror of Childbirth,'' March 20).
docs.abstract: Mary Anne Mercer letter lauds Nicholas D Kristof's March 20 column on challenges faced by pregnant women in poor countries and scores Bush administration cuts in health programs to aid such women

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women in upper Manhattan who were heavily exposed to two common insecticides had smaller babies than their neighbors, but recent restrictions on the two substances quickly lowered exposure and increased babies' size, according to a study being published today. The researchers, led by a team from Columbia University, looked at babies born to women living in Harlem and Washington Heights, and divided them into four groups, based on the amounts of the pesticides chlorpyrifos and diazinon found in the mothers' blood and umbilical cord blood. In the group with the highest levels, babies averaged 6.6 ounces lighter and one-third of an inch shorter than those in the group with no measurable amount of the insecticides in the blood.

headline.main: Babies Are Larger After Ban On 2 Pesticides, Study Finds

docs.abstract: Study finds that pregnant women in upper Manhattan who were heavily exposed to two common insecticides had smaller babies than their neighbors, but that babies' size increased after restrictions were placed on substances: chlorpyrifos and diazinon; study is part of long-running project by Columbia University researchers to gauge effects of urban pollution on mothers and children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was saddened to read that the use of midwives is declining in New York City (news article, March 15).
